File.Title: Afferent and Efferent Connections of the A5 Noradrenergic Cell Group in the Rat
File.Authors: CHRISTOPHER E. BYRUM AND PATRICE G. GUYENET

Abstract.S: The supraspinal afferent and efferent connections of the A5 noradrenergic cell group were examined in rats.
Very small deposits of HRP-WGA were made in the rostra1 A5 area.
Catecholamine histofluorescence techniques were used to confirm that the deposits overlapped the A5 column.

Retrogradely labeled cells were present in the perifornical area and paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, the Kolliker-Fuse nucleus, dorsal parabrachial area, intermediate and caudal portions of the nucleus of the solitary tract, and the ventral medullary reticular formation in the areas of the A1 and B1 cell groups.
Anterograde HRP-WGA labeling was found in several areas of the subcortical CNS.
The contribution of A5 neurons to this labeling was confirmed with retrogradely transported fluorescent latex microspheres combined with catecholamine histofluorescence techniques.

The A5 cell group was found to have significant projections to the central nucleus of the amygdala, perifornical area of the hypothalamus, midbrain periaqueductal gray, parabrachial area, and the nucleus of the solitary tract.
Other A5 projections include the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus, the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, and possibly the zona incerta and lateral and dorsal hypothalamic areas.
In addition, A5 neurons may innervate the ventrolateral reticular formation of the medulla.
Virtually all of the areas innervated by A5 noradrenergic neurons are involved in cardiovascular regulation.
In addition, the A5 area receives afferent input from major cardiovascular regulatory centers of the supraspinal CNS.
Thus the A5 cell group has the potential to exert a significant influence on the cardiovascular regulatory system.

Introduction.S: The A5 noradrenergic cell group of the ventrolateral pons appears to play an important but still poorly defined role in autonomic regulation.

The vast majority of these neurons project to the spinal cord and primarily innervate the thoracolumbar intermediolateral cell column (IML) and central autonomic area in the rat (Loewy et al., '79a; Westlund et al., '83; Byrum et al., '84).
The activity of A5 neurons is powerfully inhibited by increases in arterial pressure, an effect apparently mediated by peripheral receptors (Andrade and Aghajanian, '82; Guyenet, '84).

Moreover, electrical and chemical stimulation of the A5 area produces changes in blood pressure and heart rate (Loewy et al., '79b; Close et al., '82; Neil and Loewy, '82a; Stanek et al., '84; Woodruff et al., '84).
Finally, selective destruction of the A5 noradrenergic cells with 6-hydroxydopamine (6OHDA) alters baroreflex responses (Stornetta et al., '84).

The direct projection of A5 noradrenergic neurons to the thoracolumbar IML suggests that this cell group may exert an important influence on spinal sympathetic outflow, and the physiological evidence is consistent with participation of A5 neurons in cardiovascular regulation.
Moreover, the A5 cell group may have connections with supraspinal structures involved in cardiovascular regulation.

Anterograde and retrograde tracing studies have demonstrated descending projections from unidentified cells in the A5 area to the nucleus of the solitary tract, dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus nerve, and the ventral medullary reticular formation (Loewy et al., '79a, '81).
The A5 area may also receive input from the NTS and ventral medullary reticular formation (Norgren, "78; Ricardo and Koh, '78; Loewy and Burton, '78; Loewy et al., '81; McKellar and Loewy, '82).
In addition, the A5 area reportedly has reciprocal connections with the pontine parabrachial area (Sakai et al., '77; Saper and Loewy, '80; Loewy et al., '81).
The targets of A5 neurons above pontine levels are unknown, although A5 cells project to at least posterior diencephalic levels (Takagi et al., '80; Andrade and Aghajanian, '82; Byrum et al., '84).

Other afferent input to the A5 area may arise from the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus and the central nucleus of the amygdaloid complex (Conrad and HaE, '76; Hopkins and Holstege, "78; Hosoya et al., '83).
However, most of these suggested connections cannot be conclusively said to involve A5 noradrenergic neurons.

First. the anteromade and retrograde tracing studies examining projections of A5 area-neurons to supra-spinal structures did not demonstrate involvement of the noradrenergic neurons, which are intermingled with noncatecholamine cells of the parvicellular reticular formation (Loewy et al., '79a; Byrum et al., '84).
Second, the suggested afferent inputs to the A5 area are based entirely on autoradiographic studies reporting anterograde transport of tracer from various structures to the A5 area.
Although this technique unambiguously reveals the distribution of neuronal processes of the labeled cells, in most cases fibers of passage were not distinguished from areas of neuronal termination.
It is therefore unclear which of the demonstrated inputs to this area actually terminate on A5 area neurons.
It is evident that the afferent and efferent connections of the A5 area must be conclusively determined before realistic hypotheses can be offered regarding the functional role of the A5 group.
The present anterograde and retrograde tracing study was undertaken to clarify these connections.
Our results demonstrate that A5 noradrenergic neurons project widely to many structures involved in cardiovascular regulation.
Furthermore, the A5 area receives afferent input from major cardiovascular regulatory centers of the CNS.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Male Sprague-Dawley rats (300-400 g) were used in all experiments.

Prior to surgery, the animals were anesthetized with pentobarbital (50-60 mgkg i.p. plus boosters as needed) and received atropine sulfate (0.06-0.15 mgkg i.p.1 as needed to control respiratory tract secretions.
HRP-WGA deposits in the A5 area
The A5 noradrenergic cell group forms a narrow column of cells in the ventrolateral parvicellular reticular formation of caudal pons and rostral medulla (Byrum et al., '84).
The lateral subdivision of the A5 group is present within the rubrospinal tract, lateral to the superior olivary complex and medial to the trigeminal sensory complex (Fig. 1).
The much smaller dorsal subdivision is present above the superior olivary complex.
A small number of cells representing the caudal pole of the A5 column are present lateral to the rostral pole of the facial motor nucleus.
One series of animals (n = 22) received iontophoretic or pressure injections of HRP-conjugated wheat germ agglutinin (HRP-WGA) in the rostral part of the A5 column.

Because of the very small size of the lateral A5 subdivision in cross section (less than 0.3 mm in diameter), the A5 column was located electrophysiologically in relation to the facial motor nucleus by a previously described method (Byrum et al., '84).

The location of the rostral part of the A5 column, containing the densest accumulation of cells, was determined empirically to be 1.5-1.7 mm anterior to the rostral pole of the facial nucleus, 0.1-0.2 mm medial to its lateral edge, and 0.1 mm below its dorsal surface.
For those animals receiving iontophoretic deposits, a 1% solution of HRP-WGA (Sigma type VI) was prepared in 0.1 M sodium chloride, pH 5.7.
Glass micropipettes with tips broken to 2-3 pm were filled with the solution by vacuum.
Impedances of these microelectrodes ranged from 15 to 20 Mil in normal saline.
The microelectrode was then lowered very slowly (10 pdsecond) to the calculated location, and positive current (100 nA) was applied by an iontophoresis unit for 20-30 minutes.
The microelectrode was left in place with applied current for an equal period of time before it was very slowly withdrawn while a holding current was applied (20 nA negative).
For those animals receiving pressure injections, glass micropipettes with tips broken to 2-3 pm were filled with the tracer solution by vacuum (1% HRP-WGA in saline).

The micropipette was connected with polyethylene tubing to a pressure injection device (Picospritzer), which was triggered electronically with a stimulation unit to deliver pressure pulses at 10-second intervals (10-20 psi, 10-25-msec duration).
The meniscus height was followed visually with the aid of a dissecting microscope with a reticle.
Deposits of less than 5 nl were made over several minutes.
After injection the micropipette was left in place for 30 minutes and then withdrawn slowly with a small negative pressure applied to the system.
After a recovery period of 2 days, the animals were processed for catecholamine fluorescence and m ' reaction product by the sequential technique of Blessing et al. ('78).
The animals were anesthetized with pentobarbital and perfused intra-aortally with the Faglu solution (4% paraformaldehyde and 0.5% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer; Furness et aI,, '77).
After photographing the fluorescent cells of the A5 group (40-pm vibratome sections), the pontine sections were rinsed in ice-cold saline and refrigerated overnight.

The remainder of the brain and the midthoracic spinal cord were stored refrigerated in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) containing 30% sucrose for at least 24 hours before sectioning on a freezing microtome, collecting every third serial section (40 pm).

The tissue was processed for HRP reaction product according to the protocol of Mesulam ('78), except that the reaction solutions were continuously filtered to reduce background artifact (Gibson et al., '84).
Each section was examined under visible light (darkfield) for anterograde and retrograde labeling.

After photographing areas exhibiting the reaction product, the sections were Nissl stained and then reexamined (brightfield) to determine the distribution of the label in relation to nuclei and other structures.
In addition, photographs of the area of tracer diffusion were compared with the fluorescence photographs to determine the extent of overlap of the deposit with A5 cells.
Retrograde tracing of possible A5 projections
A second series of animals (n = 45) received injections of a retrograde tracer in selected areas of the supraspinal CNS.
Rhodamine-labeled fluorescent latex microspheres (0.02-0.2 pm diameter, Tracer Technologies) are taken up by neurons and transported retrogradely (Katz et al., '84).
Virtually no diffusion of the aqueous microsphere suspension occurs even with very large deposits (200 nl).
The undiluted microsphere suspension was injected with pressure with the aid of glass micropipettes with tips broken to 15-25 pm.
The procedure was similar to that described above, except the 50-200-nl deposits were delivered at a rate of approximately 5 nl per minute.
The animals were allowed to recover for 2 days up to 5 weeks, with no apparent loss of labeling with the longer survival times.
The perfusion and tissue-processing procedure was identical to that used in the HRP-WGA cases, with several exceptions.
The concentration of glutaraldehyde in the perfusion solution was reduced to 0.05%.
Higher concentrations of glutaraldehyde resulted in excessive background fluorescence, which partially obscured the microsphere fluorescence.
The mounted sections were coverslipped with the fluorescence mounting medium Krystalon (Harleco), which retarded the loss of catecholamine fluorescence.
The tissue containing the deposit in each case was stored refrigerated in the Faglu solution containing 30% sucrose for at least several days.
The tissue was then sectioned on a freezing microtome (40 pm), collecting every third serial section.
Alternate sections were Nissl-stained to identify the structures overlapped by the deposits.
The sections were examined under ultraviolet light with an epifluorescence microscope.

By viewing each section with blue-violet or green excitation filters, the catecholamine or microsphere (rhodamine) fluorescence was alternately visualized, allowing quantitation of singleor double-labeled cells in the A5 group.
In addition, several animals received iontophoretic deposits of HRP-WGA when necessary to avoid damage to fibers of passage.
The procedure used during injection and processing is described above.
The sequential procedure used to quantify retrograde HRP labeling of the A5 area has been described previously (Byrum et al., '84).

Results.S: HRP-WGA deposits in the A5 area
The lateral subdivision of the A5 column lies virtually entirely within the rubrospinal tract, as illustrated in Figure 1.
In addition, the A5 area contains other ascending and descending fibers, including many axons interconnecting structures involved in autonomic regulation.
For this reason, it was important to avoid damage to and thereby labeling of fibers of passage in the A5 area.

TTE.S: Of seven animals with very discrete deposits of HRP-WGA that overlapped the lateral A5 subdivision, three were rejected because of retrograde labeling of cells in the red nucleus.
As HRP-WGA does not appear to be taken up significantly by undamaged fibers (Mantyh and Peschanski, 83), such labeling potentially indicated damage to rubrospinal tract fibers in the A5 area.

Although the red nucleus projects to the trigeminal complex (Edwards, 721, the conservative approach was taken that red nucleus labeling accompanied damage to other fibers of passage in the area of the deposit.
The four cases definitely free from rubrospinal tract damage were systematically examined for anterograde and retrograde labeling.
The HRP-WGA deposits (two via iontophoresis, two via pressure) ranged in size from 0.75 to 1.5 mm in crosssectional diameter and extended 1-2 mm along the rostrocaudal axis (Fig. 2).
In each case the dense core of the deposit overlapped a majority of the fluorescent cells in the lateral subdivision of the rostral half of the A5 column.
This was determined by comparison of the deposit with photographs of fluorescent cells in the area taken prior to processing the tissue for HRP (Fig. 3).

In each case the deposit overlapped the spinal trigeminal tract, the ventral tip of the principal sensory trigeminal nucleus (PrV), and the rostral tip of the spinal trigeminal complex (SpV), as well as a very small area of parvicellular reticular formation (PcRF) and the lateral edge of the superior olivary complex (SOC).
The pattern of anterograde and retrograde labeling described below was present in all cases, except as noted.
It should be noted that anterograde refers to labeling of axons as well as terminals.
Cell counts in Table 1 represent labeled cells present on every third serial coronal section.
Neither anterograde nor retrograde labeling was present in the cerebral cortex.

Retrogradely labeled cells were not observed rostral to the optic chiasm, although anterograde labeling was present in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) and the preoptic area of the hypothalamus.

Caudal to the optic chiasm at the level of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (PVH), anterograde labeling was present with an ipsilateral predominance in the lateral hypothalamic area (LH) in and dorsal to the area of the medial forebrain bundle (MFB) (Fig. 4A).
The label extended medially around the dorsal and medial surfaces of the fornix and extended laterally to the central nucleus of the amygdala (CNA).
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in the posterior part of the lateral parvicellular subdivision of the PVH, almost exclusively on the ipsilatera1 side.
At anterior tuberal levels, predominantly ipsilateral anterograde labeling was observed in the LH, perifornical area of the hypothalamus (PFH), zona incerta (Zn, and CNA.

At this level anterograde label was present bilaterally in the dorsal hypothalamic area (DHA) and extended dorsally along the midline of the thalamus to the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus (PVT).

Retrogradely labeled cells were present with an ipsilateral predominance in the ZI centered above the fornix, although only a single cell was labeled in case 67, At caudal tuberal levels, anterograde label was present as at more rostral levels in the LH, DHA, ZI, and midline thalamus (Fig. 4B).
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in the PFH along with a prominent narrow strip of anterograde label surrounding the fornix.
Retrograde labeling of ihe ZI was present in ail cases, although only a single cell was labeled in case 67, whereas retrograde labeling of the LH was weak or absent in most cases.
Anterograde and retrograde labeling of the hypothalamus was bilateral with an ipsilateral predominance.
Frequently heavy anterograde labeling was present in the contralateral ventral posterior medial nucleus of the thalamus (VPM).
The CNA was not consistently labeled at these levels.

In the posterior hypothalamus, anterograde labeling was present in the ipsilateral LH and bilaterally on the medial surface of the now greatly elongated mammillothalamic tract and surrounding the adjacent fornix (Fig. 4C).
Anterograde labeling of the ZI was bilateral with variable strength but this structure was not retrogradely labeled at this level, and labeled cells were not consistently present in the LH or PFH.
The thalamus was labeled as at more rostral levels, with an especially dense area of anterograde label on the dorsal surface of the contralateral medial lemniscus (ML).
Anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the ventral periaqueductal gray (PAG) at the level of the posterior commissure, primarily on the contralateral side (Fig. 4D).
Only a very few cells were present in case 67.
More caudally, a particularly striking pattern of anterogradely labeled processes was present in the contralateral ventral PAG, forming a dense band arching over the oculomotor nucleus (Fig. 4E).
Prominent anterograde labeling was present bilaterally in the lateral and dorsal parts of the PAG throughout the mesencephalon.
Anterograde label was also present bilaterally with a contralateral predominance in the deep layers of the superior colliculus (SC) and in the contralateral ML.
At pontine levels, retrogradely labeled cells were present near the deposits in the ventrolateral PcRF and the ventral part of the PrV (Fig. 4F).
Anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the Kolliker-Fuse nucleus (KFN) and dorsal parabrachial area (DPB), almost exclusively on the ipsilateral side.
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in the ipsilateral locus coeruleus (LC) and ventral parabrachial area (VPB), although cells were generally few in number in these areas.
It should be noted that the dorsal and ventral subdivisions of the PBA (Paxinos and Watson, 82) are also known as the lateral and medial subdivisions, respectively.
A small number of retrogradely labeled cells were present in the contralateral ventrolateral PcRF in all cases except 48, including the contralateral A5 area.

At the level of the rostral part of the facial motor nucleus, retrogradely labeled cells were present in the vestibular complex WC), almost exclusively in the superior and medial nuclei, although only a few cells were labeled in case 67 (Fig. 4G).
Labeling in the VC varied between cases from predominantly ipsilateral to predominantly contralateral.
Sections at the level of the rostral third of the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS) were not examined.
This tissue was rendered unusable in each animal by the glue used to mount the pons for sectioning on the vibratome.

At intermediate and caudal levels of the NTS, anterograde labeling was present bilaterally in both the medial and lateral subdivisions of the NTS, primarily surrounding and ventromedial to the solitary tract (Fig. 4H).
These areas correspond to the ventrolateral, intermediate, and medial subnuclei of Loewy and Burton ( 78).
Anterograde labeling was present bilaterally in the DMNX throughout its extent, and in the reticular formation immediately adjacent to the ventrolateral NTS.
Retrogradely labeled cells also were present at intermediate and caudal levels of the NTS in the ventrolateral and medial subnuclei.
Retrograde labeling of the NTS was virtually exclusively ipsilateral except at commissural levels, where a small number of contralateral cells were labeled.
Retrograde labeling was weak or absent in more medial parts of the NTS and was never observed in DMNX.

In other areas of the caudal medulla, anterograde labeling was present on the dorsal midline, dorsal and dorsolatera1 to the medial longitudinal fasciculus and surrounding the central canal at commissural levels of the NTS.
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in this area in all cases except 48, scattered in the dorsal part of the fasciculus and also ventromedial to the NTS at precommissural levels.
Anterograde label was present bilaterally in the inferior olive (10) with a contralateral predominance.
Anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the ventral part of the ipsilateral SpV complex, with a small number of labeled cells scattered in the dorsolateral aspect.
Anterograde and retrograde label also was present in the ventral reticular formation (RF) of the caudal medulla.
Labeled processes were distributed diffusely in the area overlying and to some extent overlapping the lateral reticular nucleus (LRt), including the area of the nucleus ambiguus (NA).
At the level of the commissural NTS, a prominent strip of label extended from the ventrolateral RF dorsomedially to the ventrolateral NTS.
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in and especially dorsal to the LRt, often in close proximity to the NA.
A more medial group of labeled cells was located just lateral and dorsolateral to the 10.
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in the raphe obscurus in except 48.
Anterograde and retrograde labeling of the medullary RF was predominantly ipsilateral.
A small of the midthoracic spinal cord was also examined.
Anterograde label was present in the IML, the dorsal part of the lateral funiculus, and near the central canal.
Although the labeling was present primarily on one side of the spinal cord, it was not determined whether this was ipsilateral or contralateral to the deposit.
A very few retrogradely labeled cells were present near the central canal and medial to the lateral horn.
The cerebehm was not examined in any of the cases.

Results.S: Retrograde tracing of putative A5 projections

TTE.S: In order to clarify the sources of anterograde labeling, retrogradely transported fluorescent microspheres were deposited in selected sites in the supraspinal CNS in a series of animals.
Figure 5 illustrates the location and size of most of the sites.

In addition to the cases illustrated, one microsphere deposit overlapped the BNST at preoptic levels (case 140), and three microsphere deposits were restricted to the MFB at posterior diencephalic levels (cases 101, 106, 111).

Other microsphere deposits were placed in the somatosensory part of the cerebral cortex (case 126), cerebellar cortex (cases 98, 118, 119, 122, 123), septum (case 1341, caudateputamen (case 1241, and habenula (case 121).
Figure 6 illustrates retrograde labeling of A5 noradrenergic neurons at rostra1 and caudal levels of the A5 column.

Results.S: Table 2 indicates the extent of retrograde labeling of the A5 cell group.
Previous work has determined that each unilateral A5 group contains approximately 425 noradrenergic cells, with roughly 75% of these present in the lateral subdivision (Byrum et al., '84).
Of the cases labeling at least 10% of A5 cells (n = 20), the A5 projection was bilateral with an ipsilateral predominance (ipsilateral/contralatera1 mean = 1.3 f 0.06 SEM).
NO rostral-caudal topography of A5 projections was apparent.

The extent of A5 labeling of the dorsal part of the A5 group was generally slightly less than that of the lateral pa& (lateral/dorsal mean = 1.3 0.2 SEM ipsilateral, 1.4 + 0.2 SEM contralateral: n = 17).

TTE.S: Microsphere deposits in several areas resulted in heavy retrograde labeling of the A5 cell group.

These areas include the caudal NTS (cases 130, 135, 1361, PBA (case 1171, ventral PAG at the level of the oculomotor nucleus (case UO), lateral PAG (case 1091, PFH (case 113), CNA (case 1121, and the LH and ZI (cases 108, 114).
Conversely, iontophoretic deposits of HRP-WGA centered in several areas of medullary RF (cases 90, 92, 96, 97) notably did not label any cells of the A5 group.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Afferent input to the A5 area
Deposits of HRP-WGA in the A5 area retrogradely labeled cells in the PVH, PFH, LH, ZI, PAG, PBA, LC, F'rV, SpV, VC, intermediate and caudal NTS, and caudal ventral medullary RF.
In addition, labeled cells were present in most cases in the raphe obscurus, dorsal midline of the medulla, and contralateral pontine PcRF.
Significant numbers of retrogradely labeled cells were observed in the intermediate and caudal NTS.

This result confirms reports of anterograde labeling of the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in this portion of the NTS in the rat, cat, and monkey (Loewy and Burton, '78; Ricardo and Koh, '78; Norgren, '78; Beckstead et al., '80; King, '80).
Retrograde labeling of the ventral medullary RF was observed in two areas.
One group of cells was located primarily dorsal to the LRt, in the area of the A1 noradrenergic cell group and the caudal part of the C1 adrenergic cell group (Kalia et al., '85a,b).

This result is consistent with those of two autoradiographic studies in the rat that reported anterograde labeling of the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in the area of the Al/Cl cells (Sawchenko and Swanson, '82; McKellar and Loewy, '82).
The more medial RF cells labeled in the present study are located in the area of the B1 serotoninergic cell group (Steinbusch and Nieuwenhuys, '83).
Loewy et al. ('81) reported anterograde labeling of the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in this region in the rat.
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in significant numbers in the PBA, primarily in the KFN and DPB.
The VPB was also labeled, but very few cells were present in most cases.
This confirms the finding of Saper and Loewy ('80) of anterograde labeling of the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in the PBA.
In addition, Conrad and Pfaff ('76) found anterograde labeling of the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in the PVH in the rat.
This finding is consistent with the retrograde labeling of the PVH observed in the present study, which was restricted to the posterior part of the lateral parvicellular subdivision.
Retrogradely labeled cells were present in the PFH and LH, although few cells were observed in the LH in most cases.

Three autoradiographic studies in the rat have reported labeling of ventrolateral pontine PcRF including the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits that overlapped both the PFH and LH at tuberal levels (Hosoya and Matsushita, '81; Hosoya et al., '83, '84).

A fourth study in the rat reported anterograde labeling of the dorsal but not the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in the LH at tuberal levels that did not overlap the PFH (Berk and Finkelstein, '82).
These results, together with the weak labeling of the LH in the present study, support a projection to the lateral A5 area from the PFH but not the LH.
Retrogradely labeled cells were not observed in the amygdaloid complex in the present study.

However, autoradiographic studies in the rat, cat, and monkey have reported anterograde labeling of the pontine PcRF including the lateral A5 area with tracer deposits in the CNA (Hopkins and Holstege, '78; Hopkins et al., '81; Price, '81; Price and Amaral, '81).
These studies also indicated that the descending pathway from the CNA passed directly over the SOC.

Although the CNA may innervate A5 area cells not overlapped by the deposits in the present study, it is possible that the reported anterograde labeling of the lateral A5 area represents fibers of passage.
Finally, retrograde labeling of the ZI, ventral PAG, LC, and VC was very weak in case 67, suggesting that these areas do not provide significant input to the lateral A5 area.
Merents to the ventrolateral pons from these areas and other areas inconsistently labeled in the present study likely innervate the adjacent pontine PcRF or trigeminal complex.
It should be noted that these afferents to the A5 area must be further clarified.
The A5 area includes noncatecholamine cells in addition to the noradrenergic cells (Loewy et al., '79a; Byrum et al., '84).
Thus other techniques are necessary to conclusively demonstrate innervation of the noradrenergic cells.
Furthermore, as the HRP-WGA deposits in the present study overlapped only a fraction of A5 cells, other A5 afferents may remain unidentified.
Efferents of the A5 area
Interpretation of the pattern of anterograde labeling observed in the present study requires caution for several reasons.
The cells of origin could include noncatecholamine cells in the A5 area and adjacent structures in addition to A5 noradrenergic cells.
Furthermore, such labeling could represent anterograde labeling of collaterals of axons projecting to the area of the deposit (de Olmos and Heimer, '77).
In some cases the observed labeling likely represents axons of passage en route to or from their perikarya.

However, the labeling probably does not arise from damaged axons in the A5 area, since the absence of retrograde labeling of the red nucleus indicates the rubrospinal tract fibers surrounding the A5 cells were undamaged.

The use of the retrogradely transported fluorescent microspheres combined with catecholamine histofluorescence techniques in the present study resolves some of the ambiguity inherent in the interpretation of the pattern of anterograde HRP-WGA labeling.

In most areas exhibiting anterograde labeling, the contribution of A5 noradrenergic cells is unambiguously established, although this technique does not distinguish between axons of passage and terminal areas.
Brainstem and spinal cord
In the present study, anterograde labeling was distributed diffusely in the ventrolateral medullary RF with an ipsilateral predominance, and bilaterally in the DMNX and the caudal half of the NTS.
These results are consistent with the findings of an autoradiographic study in the rat by Loewy et al. ('79a), which examined the descending projections of cells in the A5 area.
The present retrograde tracing results (cases 125, 130, 135, 136, 138) demonstrate that A5 area innervation of the NTSDMNX arises from the noradrenergic cells.
Furthermore, more than half of the A5 cells on each side of the pons innervate each unilateral NTSLDMNX complex.
At least some A5 cells must therefore project bilaterally to the complex.
The diffuse anterograde label in the RF of the caudal medulla in the present and Loewy studies may represent areas of termination or axons of passage to the spinal cord or dorsal medulla.

The absence of retrograde labeling of the A5 group with iontophoretic HRP-WGA deposits in the dorsal and ventral medullary RF (cases 90, 92, 96, 97) is consistent with the results of two previous studies in the rat using tracer deposits in the region of the NA (Travers and Norgren, '83; Stuesse and Fish, '84).

Conversely, Andrezik et al. ('81) retrogradely labeled cells in the A5 area in the rat with tracer deposits in the ventrolateral RF, and Sun and Guyenet ('86) labeled up to 73% of A5 noradrenergic cells with C1 area microsphere deposits.
However, these results must be viewed with caution because of potential damage to fibers of passage.
Additional study is therefore necessary to resolve this point.
The present anterograde and retrograde tracing results demonstrate that the PBA is heavily innervated by the A5 group.
Anterograde labeling was present in both the KFN and DPB, with a microsphere deposit in this area (case 117) labeling half of the A5 cells bilaterally.
Projections from cells in the A5 area to the PBA have been demonstrated previously in the rat and cat (Sakai et al., '77; Loewy et al., '81).
In addition, the present results demonstrate that a large proportion of A5 noradrenergic cells project to the ventral and lateral mesencephalic PAG (cases 109, 110).
Projections from the A5 cell group to this area have not been reported by others.

Finally, in the spinal cord the anterograde labeling of the thoracic IML, central canal area, and the dorsal part of the lateral funiculus in the present study is consistent with the autoradiographic results of Loewy et al. ('79a).
Previous work has demonstrated that virtually the entire A5 group projects to at least thoracic levels (Byrum et al., '84).

In other areas of the brainstem, the anterograde labeling of the I0 and the SC arises from cells of the pontine PcRF and trigeminal complex (Baleydier and Mauguiere, '78; Berkley and Hand, '78; Edwards et al., '79; Nagata and Kruger, '79; Courville et al., '83).

In addition, the anterograde and retrograde labeling in the caudal portions of the SpV complex represents intrinsic connections with the PrV and rostral SpV (Hockfield and Gobel, '82; Lovick and Wolstencroft, '83).
Forebrain

The present anterograde and retrograde tracing results indicate that at least a third of A5 cells project bilaterally to or through the hypothalamus at posterior levels (case 108), with a substantial proportion continuing through the ipsilateral MFB to at least tuberal levels (case 107).

Prior anatomical and electrophysiological studies have demonstrated that A5 noradrenergic cells project through the MFB to at least posterior diencephalic levels (Takagi et al., '81; Andrade and Aghajanian, '82; Byrum et al., '84).
However, A5 projections to more rostral areas of the forebrain have not been identified in previous studies.
Within the hypothalamus, the PFH is innervated by at least a fifth of the A5 cell group bilaterally (case 113).
This area likely represents a terminal area for A5 axons, since prominent anterograde HRP-WGA labeling was present in a circumscribed area surrounding the fornix.
Anterogradely labeled processes were also distributed diffusely in the LH and ZI.

A large number of A5 cells were retrogradely labeled with a microsphere deposit overlapping the ZI and dorsal LH at tuberal levels (case 114), with a smaller proportion labeled with a deposit restricted to the ZI (case 133).
These results suggest that A5 axons ascend in both of these areas, although it is unclear whether these represent axons of passage or areas of termination.
In other areas of the diencephalon, anterograde labeling was observed in the DHA and midline thalamus extending to the PVT.
A single microsphere deposit that overlapped the PVT (case 139) labeled a small proportion of A5 cells.
Notably, noradrenergic innervation of the thalamus of nonLC origin is restricted to the PVT (Lindvall et al., '74).
The heavy anterograde labeling of the VPM and ML in the present study arises from the PrV (Smith, '73; Fukishima and Kerr, '79).
This was confirmed with a deposit restricted to the VPM (case 127) that heavily labeled the contralateral PrV but did not label any A5 cells.
The present anterograde and retrograde tracing results also demonstrate that approximately a fifth of the A5 cell group innervates the CNA bilaterally (case 112).
Considering the location of this structure, the anterograde labeling observed in this area likely represents a terminal area.
This finding is consistent with reports that the CNA receives a substantial noradrenergic input of non-LC origin (Fallon et al., '78; Moore and Bloom, '79; Lindvall and Bjorklund, '83).
Finally, a microsphere deposit restricted to the BNST labeled a small number of A5 cells bilaterally (case 120).

Microsphere deposits in the cerebral cortex, septum, cerebellar cortex, VPM, habenula, cortical amygdaloid nuclei, and striatum did not label A5 cells (cases 98, 103,118, 119, 121, 122,123, 124, 126, 127, 129, 131, 134).
In summary, the A5 noradrenergic cell group projects widely to structures at many levels of the subcortical CNS.
It is evident that individual A5 cells must innervate more than one target area.
Virtually all A5 cells project to the thoracolumbar spinal cord (Byrum et al., '84).
In addition, the NTS complex and PBA each receives afferent input from at least half of the A5 group.
At least a third of A5 cells innervate the PAG and a similar proportion have projections ascending to diencephalic levels.
Thus each A5 cell must innervate more than one supraspinal structure in addition to the thoracolumbar IML.
The A5 cell group is therefore similar to the LC in having axons that ramify to innervate multiple structures (Lindvall and Bjorklund, '83).
The paucity of previous reports of retrograde labeling of the A5 area with tracer deposits in various brainstem and forebrain structures requires comment.
Although it is conceivable that the relatively small A5 area was overlooked in previous studies, the most likely explanation lies in the differential sensitivity of the retrograde tracers employed.
Previous retrograde tracing studies of relevance have used free or conjugated HRP virtually exclusively.
However, false-negative results are known to occur with HRP (Nauta et al., '74), and the present results suggest that the microspheres are a much more sensitive retrograde tracer than HRP-WGA.
Moreover, it is possible that the differential sensitivity of the two tracers may be greater with certain cell types, such as those possessing widely ramifying axonal processes.
This differential sensitivity also calls into question the present suggestion that A5 cells do not terminate in the medullary RF.
